title: Divorce
intro: Hypothesis: A Christian couple can get divorced.

evidence.head: The "Porneia" Exception
evidence.short: In the Gospel of Matthew, Jesus says that it is unlawful to divorce and remarry "except for 'porneia'".
evidence.details:
Porneia ('πορνεία') is generally translated as "sexual immorality". It is related to the word for "prostitute", "porne" ('πόρνη'), and can be said to refer to "prostitution and similar". Some less literal translations render it "unfaithfulness" or similar, but it should be noted that "adultery" is "moicheia" ('μοιχεία') is a different word.

Proponents argue that Jesus here means that one is allowed to divorce an unfaithful spouse.

Critics argue that Matthew is writing to a Jewish audience and is including an exception for unlawful marriages, meaning that if one "marries" one's sister or someone else's wife, then divorcing her is of course allowed.

evidence.head: Mark on Divorce
evidence.short: The Gospel of Mark also records the discussion of divorce between Jesus and the Pharisees, but includes no exception clause.
evidence.details:
Critics argue that Jesus forbade divorce here.

Proponents argue that Mark did not include details like the exception clause, but Matthew did.

evidence.head: Luke on Divorce
evidence.short: The Gospel of Luke also records the discussion of divorce with the Pharisees, and again includes no exception clause.
evidence.details:
Critics argue that this is the second clear biblical prohibition on divorce.

Proponents argue that although Luke did not include the exception, that doesn't mean Jesus didn't, because Matthew recorded it.

evidence.head: The Pauline Privilege
evidence.short: In his first letter to the Corinthians, St. Paul relays the command Jesus gave against divorce, but allows remarriage if an unbelieving spouse leaves.
evidence.details:
Critics argue this is the third clear prohibition on divorce for Christian couples, because the exception is for when an unbelieving spouse leaves.

Proponents argue that Paul also did not include the exception from Matthew, but he included another one, which shows that not all exceptions are expected to be mentioned at all times.

evidence.head: Moses Allowed Divorce
evidence.short: The Law of Moses allowed a man to divorce his wife, and once she has been "defiled" by another, he cannot take her back.
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that this shows that God allowed divorce before, as also Jesus states, and that it is therefore not so strange that He might allow some exceptions now as well.

Critics argue that Jesus explained that this was because of the hardness of their hearts, and that it was not like this from the beginning, but Jesus came to restore God's plan for marriage by disallowing divorce.

evidence.head: Malachi: God Hates Divorce
evidence.short: Malachi says God made the husband and wife one flesh, and that He hates divorce.
evidence.details:
Critics point out that the passage even mentions unfaithfulness, suggesting that is not a good reason for divorce.

Proponents argue that divorce may not be ideal, but God still allowed it, and so unfaithfulness could still be an exception.
